key_points: Mark Zuckerberg's personal wealth fell by over $6 billion in a few hours after a Facebook outage.
The outage, which also affected Instagram and WhatsApp, lasted nearly seven hours.
Before the outage, a whistleblower, Frances Haugen, came forward, likely contributing to the financial impact.
Zuckerberg dropped to sixth place on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, behind Bill Gates, with $120.9 billion.
Facebook shares fell approximately 5%, adding to a 15% drop since mid-September.
Wall Street Journal stories based on internal documents revealed Facebook's awareness of its products' issues.
Frances Haugen, 37, revealed her identity after applying for federal whistleblower protection.
Haugen's revelations included Instagram's harm to teenage mental health, prompting Facebook to pause Instagram Kids.
Facebook VP of Global Affairs, Nick Clegg, emphasized that political polarization's issues are not solely due to technology.
The global outage was attributed to a glitch in routers, with Facebook blaming a faulty configuration change.
spokespersons: Nick Clegg (Vice President of Global Affairs, Facebook)
